text: (bright, upbeat music)
- Hello, and welcome.
My name is Ishit Vachhrajani.
I'm an enterprise strategist with AWS.
We are here to talk
about designing a cloud-enabled workforce.
As an enterprise strategist,

we are fortunate to spend time
with hundreds of executives
from some of world's largest enterprises,
and the topic of people and organization
comes up very often.
And to dive deep on this topic,

I'm excited to be joined by
Prakash Kota, CIO of Autodesk.
Prakash, welcome.
- Thanks, Ishit, for having me here.
- Prakash, can you introduce yourself?
- Yeah, sure.
I'm Prakash Kota, SVP and CIO at Autodesk.

Autodesk is changing how the
world is designed and made.
Our technology spans across architecture,
engineering, construction, manufacturing,
media, and entertainment,

and we don't believe in
just making progress.

We are there to make an
impact and make it happen

and by unleashing potential
and unlocking insights,

enabling our customers to
design and make a better world.
And with my role as a CIO,

I'm responsible for all of
our enterprise infrastructure,

our private cloud,
enterprise applications,
operations, security operations,
and also customer operations.

When customers reach out to
Autodesk, my team is accountable

and responsible for ensuring
they have a good experience.

- Awesome, thank you
for joining us, Prakash.
And speaking of making an impact,

Autodesk has a fantastic
journey to the cloud.

Can you tell us a little
bit more about your journey

to the cloud, the
successful mass migration
that you completed?

- Yeah, definitely, happy
to share our IT journey.
If you look at it about three years back,
we Autodesk had a strategic initiative
of moving our business models
to becoming a subscription company.
We used to ship DVDs to our customers,

and now we give access to
our products in the cloud.
And so with that transformation,
really triggered our thought process

of ensuring all of our
systems are highly reliable,

always available and secure,
which really made us think

about where do we want
these applications to be.

And so we decided and
embarked on this journey

to move all of our
applications to the cloud.
And that was the trigger, I would say,
of doing this mass migration program,

and I would say it was
a phenomenal journey.
We migrated over 400-plus applications,

and the best part was we also
retired a lot of applications,

which typically do doesn't
happen very often, as you know.

We're always good at investing
but when we need to divest,
that doesn't happen naturally,
and so this program really triggered that.

And also, additionally, this
also gave us an opportunity

to look at what kind of
modern experiences do we want
to give to our customers and employees
as part of this effort,

so re-architecting, in
some cases, in some cases,

as I mentioned, divesting,
in some cases, migrating.
And so it was a good journey, I would say,

from process technology
and people standpoint

on how we transformed our
applications to the cloud.
- That's very impressive, Prakash.
One of the things that we often hear
is it's about speed and agility,

and you executed this
migration at a rapid pace.

Can you talk a little bit about
how long the journey was for
and what was the timeline?

- The journey went at least
four months ahead of schedule,

which is typically
unlikely in any IT project.

But I would say one of
the reasons for it was

I'm a big believer in
going slow to go fast.

We spent a lot of time in the
beginning of this initiative

to really strategize
and agree and align on
what does an end state look like,
a good end state look like?

And then, of course, we've
followed your approach

of working backwards
and then really looked

at what outcomes do we
really want to drive,
and then came up with a plan
on how are we going to tackle it.

It was not moving all
applications at once.
We created tiger teams, I would say.
We started off with two tiger teams

in the first set of applications
where we were migrating.

We made sure folks with
lot of AWS background

and engineering knowledge
were part of the team
that helped migrate.

And then we also made
sure some team members
who were given the required training

were also shadowing the team
members who were migrating.
So we had a rhythm to it,
like we had experts who were migrating,

and we had a partner we
leveraged who helped us
in the first few migrations,

and then, the next set of team
members were getting training
and then certifications,
then shadowing the particular migrations

were then next allowed
to actually migrate,

which means we brought
the entire team along
in this journey.
It was not just about leveraging a partner
and having them do the work for us,
while we started off engaging a partner

to help us train the team
and then upskill the team,
but then we made sure our teams were part
of the overall migration efforts
in bringing all the applications over,
whatever we wanted to bring to the cloud.

- Great, and you talked
about sort of the speed
and how bringing your team along
was a key part of that journey.
Can you talk to us a little bit
about how did you assess the skills
of the team that you had?
What were the gaps?
You talked about re-skilling and training,
augmenting that with other resources.

How did you assess the
skillset you had in-house,

and what was the plan
that you put together
to rapidly re-skill the team?

- Yeah, no, I think that's
a good question, actually.

First, we defined what roles
and skillsets do we need
for the future and for migration,

and so we also made sure
that all the team members,
as I mentioned, we defined the roles
and their responsibilities and skill sets
that are required for the future,
not what they have today,
and how are we going to leverage them,

and what kind of
certifications do they need?
And so we also have this 70/20/10 concept

where 70% of your knowledge
gaining happens on the job,
and 20% happens working with your peers,

and 10% is like I would
call it classroom training.

So they start off with that
10%, getting classroom training,

getting certifications, and
then they spend a lot of time

while they're shadowing the
tiger teams who are migrating.
They spend time with the peers,

get the required knowledge
and test it out and try.

And then they actually,
when they become part

of the tiger team, when
they're migrating applications,
that's when they really start learning,
and that's the 70% of the job.
So we follow this concept,

and as they successfully
migrated applications

and we defined what does
an end state look like,
then we also did a lot of gamification
where we said, "Okay, you know what?
Their titles are going to change.
You need to earn these badges
on how you are going to be,"
healthy competition within the team
across the globe, actually.
So there was a lot of good competition.

Which part of the globe
is really migrating fast
with high quality?

It was not just migrating, but
migrating with high quality
because at the end of the day,
we really didn't want the business folks,
our business applications to even realize

that something was
happening behind the scenes.

The infrastructure change
from our hosted data centers
to the cloud was seamless.
We didn't have any specific downtime

or maintenance windows
to make this migration.

And that was the challenge
given to the team.
How do we do that?
We don't wanna stop the business

while we are making
all these foundational,

fundamental changes to moving
the applications to the cloud.
And so that was the approach.

It was more about up-skilling
them, making them shadow,
getting them the confidence
and then putting them on the job, ensuring
that they are actually doing the work.
That's how they get expertise.

- Sounds like you had a
very thoughtful approach,

but that didn't slow you
down, which is amazing.

There are a couple of things
that you talked about,
which are very interesting,
and I wanna double-click on them.
You mentioned gamification

and sort of teams had
to earn these badges.

Can you tell us a little
bit more about that?

- Yeah, no, I think, see,
at the end of the day,

if they're doing different
jobs and different activities,

they can't be carrying their
legacy titles and job titles.

There is not a satisfaction
that employees will have.
So we were very clear.
You won't also get new titles
if you keep performing what you're doing
because I'm a big believer

you need to change your actions
to get different results.
You can't keep taking same actions
and expect different results.

So when employees are starting
to take different actions
and start performing different activities,

you need to really recognize
them, what they're doing

and what appropriate titles
do we need to give them.

And so we identified, we
defined job profiles, actually.

What does a go forward
job profiles look like,

whether it is cloud engineers,
full stack engineers,

DevOps engineers, data
scientists, cloud architects,
whatever those roles could be?

And each one required
certain number of hours,

certain certifications
for them to complete

and for certain activities
for them to maintain
and do and own ongoing basis.

And so when they achieved
those milestones,

we actually gave them
those specific titles.
So we evolved and changed their titles,

job titles to those roles,
which really gave them,
like it was a personal satisfaction
that the milestone that they achieved.
It's also not a big win for Autodesk
while they migrated applications.

They also saw that, okay,
it's my personal milestone

for me to get to a cloud
engineer, cloud architect
or a DevOps engineer, full stack engineer.
And that really motivated engineers
because when you incentivize team members
with a particular what is in it for them,
what is in it for me, they are motivated.

They get the energy and
drive that is required

for them to go beyond,
above and beyond to perform.

So that's what we really
saw with the team.

And also, based on the
number of certifications,
we also ensured Autodesk took care
of all the certifications.
We paid for the certifications,

and we also made sure in
all of the migration program
within the sprints, we allocated some time
for training and certifications.

So it was not like okay, we
are expecting you to work 40,

50 hours a week and then
somehow you're gonna manage
to finish training certifications
and expect to be ready to do.
A lot of realistic expectations were set,

and lot of room was given to
employees to be successful.
That really helped them.

People felt like they had
a lot of personal gain

while Autodesk also
benefited from this program.
- Great insights there.
I love the idea of actually making room
and time for learning.

So you actually had sort
of training and learning
as part of your sprint planning

and how you located the
capacity, which is great

because often we hear that
people just don't have time
from their day-to-day job to spend
in training and certification.
They like to do it,
but they simply don't have the bandwidth.
So that's a great idea.
Did the structure of the team change?

- I mean, it did change
because if you look at it,

when you have a complete set
of data center engineers,

storage engineers, computer
engineers, Linux, Unix,
and Windows kind of skillsets to now,
you're talking about full stack engineers.

You're talking about
infrastructure as code.
So you're talking about cloud engineers,
cloud architects, DevOps engineers,
site reliability engineers

when you're talking about
complete availability,
reliability, and security.
So the roles evolved and changed a lot
because when we leverage cloud,
we also have certain expectations

on what we expect AWS as a
cloud provider to provide,

which we probably when we are
hosting our own data centers,
we need to be responsible for.

So now they're spending a lot
of time on the capabilities

that exist in the cloud,
how to tap onto them

and how to bring that value to
our customers and our users.
That's where they spend a lot of time
rather than just hosting.
And so what they needed to do
is more about continuous learning

because you guys are
launching services regularly,
which is the best part of a cloud provider
when we engage with the cloud provider.

It's not just about the
core infrastructure.
It's about the surrounding capabilities
that come along with it.
And so they're continuously learning
and then bringing what does any
of these services bring value to Autodesk?

And if they, how do we enable,
how do we start consuming?
So that's where they spend a lot of time.
So I think their roles changed.

The activities they do on
a day-to-day basis changed,

like the maintenance
activities that they are doing
when you are in a data center
to what they don't need to do today,
because it those are expectations

for a public cloud provider to
provide us, is so different.

So the operational nature
of reactively working
on certain things has completely changed

to more proactively
thinking of making sure

that you're continuously
reliable, available and scalable
and secure is where the focus is.

- One of the things that
we often see that, Prakash,

what you talked about is that
teams don't have to spend time
on undifferentiated heavy lifting.

So they can actually focus on
really growing the business

and doing something that
your customers care for

rather than that
undifferentiated heavy lifting,

and that impacts the titles,
roles, as well as structure
of the organization because you're able
to now innovate much faster.
As you look back at your journey
and some of the results that you've seen,

how do you think this
has helped you retain
and attract the talent?
Because there's just so much focus

on companies trying to
differentiate their business

that they need to
attract the right talent.
How does that actually help you?

- See, one of the key things
with cloud is the agility,

how frequently you can add
value to your customers,
and us being a cloud company,

we are always doing things,
putting customer at the center.
And our goal is to how do we make sure
we give continuous value to our customers,

and that is definitely, that
agility that we are looking for
is definitely available with cloud.

And that is something that
is unlocking our employees

to really take advantage
of what cloud brings.

So going away from annual
or semi-annual releases

or releasing features to
customers on a quarterly basis

to you can release stuff
multiple times a day
is a significant thing,

and it's also a lot of
satisfaction for them,

how quickly they can turn
around and start contributing
and adding value.

And it also feels good because
ultimately our customers win.
Our customers are getting the most value.
And also, in a traditional,

when you're doing stuff,
maintaining your data centers
and hosting, you are behind the scenes.
When you're an infrastructure resource,
you're behind the scenes.
Nobody even knows that a person exists.
But when you're consuming cloud
and you are tapping on additional value

that you're bringing to the
teams and launching features

so that your consumers
can benefit out of it,

you are able to be directly
making connection to the value
that we are generating to customers.
So that's a significant shift and change
in really motivating talent
and giving them challenging work

because see, one of the biggest
reasons why employees leave

is because either they have
a problem with their manager

or they don't like whom
they report or work to
or they don't have challenging work.
Yes, people talk a lot about compensation,

but, as you know, we're
based in Silicon Valley.
We give competitive salaries,
so it's not just about salaries.

It's also about am I
having interesting work,
am having challenging work,

and am I contributing
and creating an impact,

and is the company adding a
purpose to whatever we do?

So all of these factors
really are important
to retain employees or to attract talent,
and I feel like we are able to do that.
- Great.

Looking ahead, what are some
of the things that you see next

for Autodesk in this journey,
as well as your teams?
What are the new roles?
What do you think is next for your team?
- Yeah, I think the next big thing, right,
I would say we are definitely focusing
on leveraging data with a cloud company
and a subscription company.

If we wanna continuously
deliver value to our customers,

whether it's internal
employees or external,

we wanna make sure we
understand our customers well,

which means we wanna make
sure we give personalization
to our employees.

Then we want to know where
are they spending most
of the time?
What kind of activities are they doing?
How do we remove friction

so that they can have more
self-service or things on demand?

So we are looking at how
do we tap into the data

that is available and the
compute power that's available

with the cloud to really
give experiences on the fly,
so lot of focus on personalization,

lot of focus on making
sure we are giving unique

and appropriate experiences,
consumer-like experiences,

whether it's our employees
or partners or customers.
So there is a huge focus on that,

which is exciting, actually,
as we start learning

because we all think, especially
when you are IT leaders

and technology leaders,
you bring in so many tools

and applications, and
when you start learning
what is adding more value to your users,
it's fascinating to learn.
And it's also helping understand,

especially for our employee
population where we have a lot

of tools and applications,
it also gives us a flavor

of not us thinking what
is important for them,

but the data proves and tells
what is important for them.

And so we are able to focus
on those specific tools

and capabilities and also
divest in our other tools
that are not adding that much value.

So it's also simplification
that's happening,

and it's also modernization
that's happening in parallel.

So I would say it's a fascinating
time to be in this field,
trying to leverage the cloud data

to transform, ultimately
to give transformative

or consumer-like
experiences to your users.

- Sounds like a really
fun workplace experience

transformation that you're
embarking on, as well.
Prakash, as you think about your journey,

some of the successes that
you had, what is next,
what will be your advice?

What are the top three things
that you would tell your peers
who are thinking about this transformation
or are just starting out their journey?

- See, the first thing I'll
say is don't move to cloud
with a cost mindset.
Definitely have a value mindset.

In some cases, you may be
spending a little bit more,
but as long as you're getting value,
because I'm a big believer

in cost is what you pay,
value is what you get.
So have a value mindset, and that's one.

The second thing is, as I
mentioned, go slow to go fast.

What I mean by this is
in the initial stages,
coming up with a proper plan
from how are you gonna leverage cloud,
who are the partners who you are going

to be associated with who are
going to help you, enable you,
and also the employees portion of it,
like how are you going to help them train

and focus on learning,
continuous learning,

and how is it going to
be part of the program
and not an additional thing,
and having a structure and governance
on how are you gonna measure the outcomes
is going to be very critical.

So make sure you guys
do spend time on that.
And then, also set expectations
to your users on what to expect.
And the other thing is celebrate.
Celebrate continuously

because change management
is the critical element
in the second point that I mentioned
with all of the activities.
Don't underestimate the change management
of what the new world is going to be.
And it takes a lot of iterations

to really ensure you're
focusing on that with the teams,

and I think that structure
will really help all of you
to be successful.
And when things don't go right, it's fine.
Make sure you are embracing that
and you're sharing with your team

and explaining it on
what learnings we have
and how are we going to move forward.
And when they are successful, I mean,
whether they're successful

or when you have learnings,
celebrate continuously

because then that gives
them the confidence.
"You know what?

The management is not
looking at us even if we fail
or if we make a mistake."
That gives them confidence to move faster,
and that gives a lot of good outcomes.
- Some pretty sage advice, Prakash,
I really enjoyed our conversation.

Thank you so much for
sharing your insight,
and I'm really excited to see what you
and Autodesk team does next.
Thank you so much.
- No, thank you very much for having me.
(bright, upbeat music)
